## Key Themes and Analysis

### Good and Evil Reversal

The Master and Margarita explores the complex relationship between good and evil, presenting them as connected rather than opposing forces. Good and Evil need to coexist as depicted in the conversation between Woland and Matthew the Levite: "What would happen if there is no evil or shadow, everyone has a shadow." Both need to exist to appreciate the good.

Woland, the Devil in the book is an ambiguous character; he is like a human character. When it comes to his deeds, there is no clear distinction between good and bad. Woland is an ambiguous character who is able to feel sorry and compassionate after killing of Berlioz.

### Biblical Parallels

The novel contains extensive biblical parallels through its dual narrative structure. Though the two parts of the novel are set centuries apart, the action in both unfolds in parallel over the course of five days (Wednesday to Sunday). The chapters consisting of the Jerusalem story are woven into the lives of the Moscow characters.

Within the novel, we see a very similar unfolding of events as the Bible. In the novel, Pilate persecutes Yeshua, and sensing his mistake, Pilate kills Judas. Considered in the context of its time, Pilate's firm condemnation of Yeshua parallels Stalin's reign of terror.

The novel's allusions to Pontius Pilate provide biblical grounding. Bulgakov summons the gospel to life through a vivid reimagining of its narratives. The story of Ha-Nozri's trial and crucifixion is a religious cornerstone and literary centerpiece.

### Soviet Satire

Bulgakov employs Aesopian language in order to criticize the hypocrisy of Soviet society. A 1930s retelling of the Dr. Faust story in the Soviet Union, Bulgakov delivers his semi-disguised, shattering critiques of Stalin's regime through the antics, gaslighting, and mockery carried out by Woland.

Mikhail Bulgakov's The Master and Margarita uses satire to examine Soviet society's absurdities and moral issues. The arrival of the Devil, Woland, in Moscow leads to disorder, exposing corruption in daily Soviet life.

Bulgakov did not believe in the promised 'glorious Communist future', and his novel displays this conviction through criticisms of Soviet society and political ideology.

### Literary Significance

The Master and Margarita combines supernatural elements with satirical dark comedy and Christian philosophy, defying categorization within a single genre. Many critics consider it to be one of the best novels of the 20th century, as well as the foremost of Soviet satires.

Witty and ribald, the novel is also a philosophical work that wrestles with profound and eternal problems of good and evil. By turns a searing satire of Soviet life, a religious allegory to rival Johann Wolfgang von Goethe's Faust, and an untamed burlesque fantasy.

The novel's enduring relevance stems from its exploration of universal themes through the lens of authoritarian critique, making it a powerful work that transcends its specific historical context while offering profound insights into human nature, power, and moral complexity.
